name: Prism
description: A triangular glass object that separates white light into its constituent colors by bending each wavelength at a different angle.
fact: A prism demonstrates dispersion, the property that different colors of light travel at slightly different speeds through a medium, causing the familiar rainbow effect when white light passes through.

name: Birefringent Crystal
description: A type of crystal, like calcite, that splits incoming light into two beams traveling at different speeds and angles.
fact: Birefringent crystals reveal the fascinating property of double refraction, where a single ray of light is split into two rays, creating a doubled image when viewed through the crystal.

name: Quantum Dot
description: A nanoscale semiconductor that can absorb photons and re-emit them at specific wavelengths, depending on its size.
fact: Quantum dots change color based on their size due to the quantum property of photon absorption and emission, making them useful in ultra-precise imaging, television displays, and solar cells.

name: Blackbody
description: An idealized object that absorbs all incident light and emits radiation based on its temperature.
fact: A blackbody shows the property of thermal radiation, emitting light across the spectrum, from infrared to visible, which is why objects like stars glow in different colors depending on their temperature.

name: Optical Fiber
description: A thin, flexible strand of glass or plastic that transmits light over long distances by bouncing light within its core.
fact: Optical fibers rely on total internal reflection, a process that allows light to travel through the fiber without escaping, enabling high-speed internet communication across oceans and continents.
